thread.title: Who would lead a coalition government and how would it be formed?

author: Mike Kelly
title: Who would lead a coalition government and how would it be formed?
text:
News Who would lead a coalition government and how would it be formed? We look at the options after an extraordinary night in British politics which has seen a hung parliament Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Even with the results of the 2017 general election still to come in, the back stage plotting about what happens next on this extraordinary night had begun. 
What is clear, despite being the largest party, is that Theresa May ’s position is virtually untenable as leader of the Conservative party. 
It was her gamble to call a snap election to strengthen her hand at the Brexit negotiation. 
That gamble has spectacularly backfired, the party actually losing seats, and already Tory MPs are reportedly ‘spitting feathers’ about it. 
In her acceptance speech after winning her Maidenhead constituency she talked of a ‘period of stability’ and the Conservative party ‘doing what was in the national interest’. Ruth Davidson, Boris Johnson and Theresa May (Photo: PA/Getty) 
That, ultimately, will likely mean she stands down. 
Who decides on a coalition? 
As the incumbent government the Tories get the first chance at creating a coalition. 
It is unlikely it can form one with any of the major parties so it might have to go with the unionist MPs in Northern Ireland. 
Even then it might not quite get the 326 seats required for a majority. 
Its option then is govern with a minority of MPs but it would have to pass a Queen’s speech with the help of another or more than one other party. Read More 
Who would be Prime Minister? 
With Mrs May’s authority undermined, it will see other figures jockeying for position. 
Already Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is being talked of as a replacement. 
However, Johnson is a divisive figure. One person who is not is Ruth Davidson, the leader of the Tories in Scotland who has had a great night north of the border. 
She has previously said she would not be interested in taking the top job, but these are extraordinary times with Brexit negotiations due to start in about 10 days time. 
What if the Tories can't make a deal? 
If the Tories can’t come up with a solution, it would be down to Labour. 
Before the election, Mr Corbyn said there would be ‘no deals’ as the Tories spoke of a coalition of chaos. 
If it were indeed to form a coalition it would have to be with more than one party - a so-called ‘rainbow coalition’. 
Theoretically the two main parties could get together in what is known as a ‘grand coalition’ but that isn’t going to happen. 
And if Labour can't make it work? 
Another possibility for a pact is a looser “confidence and supply” arrangement. This means the minor party or parties would commit to voting with the government on key events - for example Brexit - such as the budget and Queen’s speech, but take all other votes on a case-by-case basis. Read More
